name: Silent adventures (Hollow Knight - Education)
description: Videogames, film and TV usually rely on the spoken word to communicate character and story. It wasn’t always this way. Although we may think of ‘silent films’ as in the past, there are contemporary videogames and films that shy away from using the spoken word.

key_work.title: Hollow Knight
key_work.brief_description: Hollow Knight is an award-winning platforming game developed by Australian indie studio Team Cherry.

constellations_other.name: Creepy crawlies onscreen
constellations_other.description: This constellation celebrates creepy crawlies on screen, whether they are benevolent heroes like Buddy the spider of Sbug Games’ Webbed (2019), inscrutable arthropods, or arachnid villains.

constellations_other.name: Transfiguration
constellations_other.description: Transfiguration follows the cycle of evolution through a figure who transforms through the elements, from lava and rock to diamonds and steam. Creatures born from the elements have long been part of screen culture.

end.title: Faxanadu
end.brief_description: Faxandu is for the Famicom and NES. The name was licensed by Falcom and was developed and released in Japan in 1987. Nintendo also released the game to the world market in 1990. It can be considered a side-story of Xanadu, which is the second installment of Falcom’s long-running RPG series, Dragon Slayer. The title is a combination of “Famicom” and “Xanadu”

constellations_other.name: Silent adventures (Hollow Knight - Education)
constellations_other.description: Videogames, film and TV usually rely on the spoken word to communicate character and story. It wasn’t always this way. Although we may think of ‘silent films’ as in the past, there are contemporary videogames and films that shy away from using the spoken word.

links.description: Hollow Knight features a silent protagonist and uses written text for interactions with non-playing characters. This pays homage to older role-playing games which were made before recorded dialogue was possible. The creators wanted to “replicate the… wonder and discovery” of games like Faxanadu.

start.title: WALL·E
start.brief_description: WALL·E is the last robot left on an Earth that has been overrun with garbage and all humans have fled to outer space. For 700 years he has continued to try and clean up the mess, but has developed some rather interesting human-like qualities.

constellations_other.name: Distributed Consciousness
constellations_other.description: Distributed Consciousness mixes NFT technology and custom AI software created by the artist to question artificial intelligence, ecology, sustainability, consciousness and free will - just like the works in this Constellation.

end.title: A Grand Day Out
end.brief_description: Wallace and Gromit have run out of cheese and this provides an excellent excuse for the animated duo to take their holiday on the moon, where, as everyone knows, there is ample cheese. The moon is inhabited by a mechanical caretaker, who is not too happy about the two visitors from earth that nibble on the moon.

links.description: Pixar may have taken some inspiration from Wallace and Gromit’s A Grand Day Out, where the duo encounters a silent, clean-obsessed robot on the moon. Gromit also doesn’t speak, with the animators relying on character design and animation to express Gromit’s feelings.

end.title: LIMBO
end.brief_description: This minimalist puzzle-platform game succeeded in making esoteric and artistic games popular with broader audiences, defying the idea that indie games were ‘timewasters’ or commercially unviable, with LIMBO topping countless ‘Game of the Year’ lists and selling over 1 million copies worldwide.

constellations_other.description: Videogames, film and TV usually rely on the spoken word to communicate character and story. It wasn’t always this way. Although we may think of ‘silent films’ as in the past, there are contemporary videogames and films that shy away from using the spoken word.

links.description: Faxanadu featured a nameless character just like Limbo, which helped popularised the side-scrolling genre. In Limbo, players must navigate the game without any spoken or written words. Unlike Faxanadu, this was a choice rather than the result of sound chips not being available.

links.description: Players learn Limbo‘s mechanics through trial and error; the story world communicated through visuals, sound effects and player interactions. The first 40 minutes of Wall-E has no dialogue, instead, the bleak vision of future Earth is communicated entirely through clean-obssessed Wall-E’s actions.
